ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: As a foreigner, I have learned a lot about American society, history, politics, and communities.
Trying to think like an anthropologist. I have learned how anthropology works and how to they observe our society. Social-political views and some economic structures about our world.
I developed the skill of learning how to break down a text rather than sit there and blindly read through.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: For me, someone whose native language is not English and who didn't grow up in the U.S., the reading assignment before class is too much and too dense to process.
I think my weaknesses in this course was feeling involved and I think we couldve changed that by having a more set structure in what we were going to do for the day.

It confused me a lot at the beginning (Maybe because I am a stem student in China). However, the professor is so helpful, I finally understand this course. Still, my essay and thoughts is so poor. Maybe I can read more books and articles about social science to improve my thoughts.
The strengths i had in this course was being able to engage with my classmates, but my weaknesses were understanding the complex material.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments:
I would recommend it to someone who has a certain amount of interest in American politics, society, sociology, people, etc. 

Meanwhile, I suggest that some indication that this course focuses on American anthropology could be added to the place of choosing courses. I understand that this is a default piece of information as we are in the U.S., but many international students might not realize this.
Yes, this course was a very fun and intriguing course to take that really helps open your mind to different ways of viewing society.
Yes. If they are interested in social science.
Yes i would recommend this course to other students because it's a different course , you learn about different socialities across the world.

narratives.question_text: The Canvas course site allowed me to identify and access required course materials easily.
comments: Strongly Agree
Agree
Agree
Strongly Agree
Agree
Agree

narratives.question_text: How will you use the knowledge and skills you learned in this course in your future endeavors?
comments:
Disciplines inside the scope of humanities and social science subjects are all interconnected. As a student studying in the humanities faculty, this course is definitely helpful to my future studies. 
For me, the biggest reward for taking this course has to be my improvement in reading academic papers. I can sense my muscle for academic reading growing by the day. I'm really pleased about it. 
In terms of concrete knowledge from the course, I'm grateful that I know much more about American Anthropology than three weeks ago. And as someone who didn't grow up physically in the U.S. but has always been virtually living in the English world through the Internet and whatnot, the knowledge from this course is a valuable asset.
I will you the skills learned in this class to be more productive while reading, analyze, and annotating text.
Maybe I can use essay skills in the future.
I will use the way he taught me how to break down text in my other courses.

extras.title: ANTH S110 01 - Intro to Cultural Anthropology
